üìö Array DS - Reverse an Array

By Amir Charkhi | AI Tech Institute

üéØ Purpose

Master the fundamental problem of reversing an array - a core skill that appears in countless coding interviews and real-world applications. This tutorial will walk you through multiple approaches, helping you understand when to use each method.

üìã Problem Statement

Given an array of integers, reverse the array and return it.

Example:
Input: [1, 4, 3, 2]
Output: [2, 3, 4, 1]

Input Format

  • First line: integer n, the number of elements
  • Second line: n space-separated integers

üí° Solution Approach 1: Python Slicing

The most Pythonic way to reverse an array. While elegant, it creates a new array rather than modifying in-place.

def reverseArray(arr): """ Reverse an array using Python slicing. Args: arr: List of integers Returns: Reversed list """ return arr[::-1]

‚è±Ô∏è Time Complexity

O(n) - must copy all elements

üíæ Space Complexity

O(n) - creates new array

üí° Best for: When you need a new reversed array and want clean, readable code.

üí° Solution Approach 2: Two-Pointer Technique

This approach uses two pointers starting from both ends of the array, swapping elements until they meet in the middle. This is the preferred method when you need to modify the array in-place.

Visualization

Initial array:

1
4
3
2

left ‚Üí points to index 0
‚Üê right points to index 3

After swapping:

2
4
3
1

Continue until left >= right

def reverseArray(arr): """ Reverse an array using two-pointer technique (in-place). Args: arr: List of integers (will be modified) Returns: The same list, reversed in-place """ left = 0 right = len(arr) - 1 # Swap elements until pointers meet while left < right: arr[left], arr[right] = arr[right], arr[left] left += 1 right -= 1 return arr

‚è±Ô∏è Time Complexity

O(n) - visits each element once

üíæ Space Complexity

O(1) - only uses constant extra space

üí° Best for: When you need in-place modification or want to demonstrate algorithmic thinking in interviews.

üîç Step-by-Step Walkthrough

Two-Pointer Method Example:

  1. Initialize: left = 0, right = 3 (for array [1, 4, 3, 2])
  2. Iteration 1: Swap arr[0] and arr[3] ‚Üí [2, 4, 3, 1], left = 1, right = 2
  3. Iteration 2: Swap arr[1] and arr[2] ‚Üí [2, 3, 4, 1], left = 2, right = 1
  4. Stop: left (2) >= right (1), so we're done!

üéØ Key Takeaways

  • Python slicing ([::-1]) is elegant but creates a new array
  • Two-pointer technique is space-efficient and demonstrates strong algorithmic skills
  • Both approaches have O(n) time complexity, but differ in space usage
  • In interviews, the two-pointer method often shows deeper understanding

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfalls

  • Forgetting the loop condition: Use while left < right, not while left != right (handles even-length arrays correctly)
  • Modifying original array: If you need to preserve the original, make a copy first
  • Off-by-one errors: Remember that right starts at len(arr) - 1

üìö Practice Recommendations

  • Try implementing both approaches
  • Practice with edge cases: empty array, single element, already reversed array
  • Consider how you'd implement this in other languages (Java, C++)
  • Think about variations: reverse only part of an array, reverse words in a string
